data.title: incorrect command line help shown for uninstall-extension
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version:Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run code-alpha --help

Shown as "list-extensions", should be "uninstall-extension"

```
 --list-extensions     List the installed extensions.
  --install-extension <extension>
                        Installs an extension.
  --list-extensions <extension>
                        Uninstalls an extension.
```

See https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/b455db9f356a9e395aefa44d9b3f5597c67b7aa0#diff-e255a28340d4f20061d11494e99bd60b

data.title: Install only supported extensions
data.body:
## Proposal

**Givens:**
- An extension called "Acme" has released 3 versions, each version has developed on the following VSCode version (just for the example)...
  - Acme v1.0.0 on VSCode v0.10.3
  - Acme v1.7.0 on VSCode v0.10.10
  - Acme v2.0.0 on VSCode v1.1.0
- User is using VSCode v1.0.0

**Events:**
User wants to install Acme extension. User open the command palette and search for Acme extension then click Install.

**Expects:**
VSCode should install Acme v1.7.0 instead of Acme v2.0.0 since the Acme extension's developer might use newer API calls that are not exist in VSCode v1.0.0 which can leads to extension crash.
## Potential Solutions
1. Let VSCode query only compatible version of the extensions upon install, update.
2. Allow developers to specify minimum VSCode version on each extension submission (potentially `packages.json`).

data.title: [git] File is shown under `Changes` even when all changes have been staged
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-inside
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a file which has changes
2. Select some lines, and click on `Stage Selected Lines` in the ellipsis menu on top-right.
3. When you've staged all the lines, the file is still there in the **Changes** section.

What Should Happen:
File should be immediately removed from the changes section when all it's changes have been staged.

data.title: .d.ts files not recognized during compilation if camel-cased
Editor should be focused immediately after switching working files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open several working files
2. Switch current working file by clicking on it in Working Files pane
3. Now the focus is in Explorer view, although user (me) expects it to be in editor instead

One of the consequences of this issue is that it is inconvenient to copy and paste text between working files. User can't press Ctrl+V immediately after switching current file as the editor is not focused.

data.title: [ts] Missing syntax highlighting for async arrow functions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0
- OS Version:Win10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create .ts file
2. paste `let f = async (x) => {};`

The result should be a blue `async` and a cyan colored `x`. 
When writing `let f2 = async function(x) {};` the async is colored blue.

![async-highlighting](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16759855/15180324/217905b2-1781-11e6-9ce0-1121372e2930.png)

data.title: High cpu load when opening typescript projects
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a folder with vscode containing a typescript project
2. Start Windows Task Manager and look for code.exe processes

The process  _code.exe_  with the parameter _"...\resources\app\extensions\typescript\out\utils\electronForkStart"_ consumes constantly between 8 and 11 percent of cpu.
The memory of the code.exe process is constanly increasing by time.

The problem only occures on some machines. On other machines (also Windows 7 and same version of vscode) opening the same project works fine.

I've already added all external folders containing ts files to _files.watcherExclude_ in my settings file, but that didn't change anything.

Any ideas how to fix this problem?

![vscodetaskmgr](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18679406/15179891/a5a91c1c-177e-11e6-99a3-ae1b1bdabcfe.png)

data.title: Edits fail to validate ranges correctly before applying
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1
- OS Version: OSX

Affected `beautify` for VS Code. HookyQR/VSCodeBeautify#14
Steps to Reproduce:

Create extension and, with a file open with content:

``` javascript
const active = vscode.window.activeTextEditor;
let range = new vscode.Range(0, 0, Number.MAX_VALUE, Number.MAX_VALUE);
active.edit(edit => edit.replace(range,"new"));
```

Previously (v1.0 and lower) this would replace the file content with "new" as the edit call would validate the range by reducing the infinite end to the end of the file. From version 1.1 (including insider) the infinite end is set to zero instead.

`document.validateRange` still performs as expected.

I have changed my extension to call `validateRange` before any edits, but I believe the way the edits worked previously is more logical.

data.title: Cannot read property 'stopTime' of undefined
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. `cmd` + `shift` + `P`
2. `> Developer: Startup Performance`
3. `Enter`

=> `[error] Cannot read property 'stopTime' of undefined`

Restarting vscode fixed the problem. I know have a proper message:

`[info] Command 'Developer: Startup Performance' is not enabled in the current context.`

Not sure if it's a one-time bug auto-fixed but that might worth to take a look into it.

assume that I want to harness 'fs' module features.naturally I have a code like:
`var fs=require('fs');`
then when I want to read a file or define a stream to a file for writing I expect when I type `fs` a variety of different options would be displayed.but it seems modules are unknown for VSCode and ,if  so,this is an extremely significant failure .
please guide me if there is a solution what's that.this case occurs for `child_process` and other modules too.

data.title: Add option to convert all tabs to spaces (not only indentation)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create new file.
2. Insert text like:

aaa`<TAB>`bbbb
aaaaaa`<TAB>`bbbb
aaaaaaaa`<TAB>`bbbb
1. Go to File/Preferences/User Settings and add this line "editor.tabSize": 10
2. Check all Bs from step 2 are aligned on the left side. Check As and Bs are separated by one tab and not by spaces.
3. Implement option "Convert Tabs to Spaces" such that after the conversion, the way the text is displayed does not change (take into account that a `<TAB>` has a variable width when it is displayed on the screen). This conversion should work for all tabs in a document, not only for identation.

data.title: Debug console trims whitespaces since 1.1.0
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. log something with whitespaces
- `console.log("     hello");`
- `console.log("\t\thello");`
- `console.log(JSON.stringify({a: 1, b: {c: "hello"}}, null, " "));`
- `console.log(JSON.stringify({a: 1, b: {c: "hello"}}, null, "\t"));`

The debug console trims every whitespace.
![trim](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7387621/15173695/dc61a24a-175d-11e6-9284-1dda52cecd1d.PNG)

data.title: Add tooltips to git viewlet items
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch app and open any folder which has long file name
2. Click on Git icon from action container list.
3. Click on "initialize Git.." to map the folder with git repo.
4. Verify file content under Git Viewlet.
5. Hove over on any file which is truncated due to long name.
Actual: User is not able to see full file name with mouse hover. 
Expected: User should get file name when perform mouse hover.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/15167067/5f80ca18-16da-11e6-83ee-422c8ef6c930.png)

data.title: Not getting any message in the output console when getting issue with git operation.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10
  Steps to Reproduce:
- launch app and open any folder which contains smoke test project. 
- Click on "Initialize Git repository" to map.
- Click on more icon (...) and perform operation "Undo latest commit".
- Verify error message should be displayed with below text.
  Note:  This is expected as folder is not mapped with any GIT repo.
  "There was an issue running a git operation. Please review the output or use a console to check the state of your repository."
- Click on "show output" button and verify error message in the console output for git.

Actual: There is no error message showing up in the console output for GIT.
Expected: User should get info in the output window.
![gitoutputissue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/15166875/14f39928-16d8-11e6-8a0c-f328aef63aa8.gif)

data.title: Python print unicode generate error in output window

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.1
- OS Version:Win7 64bit, Python 2.7.8

Steps to Reproduce:
**Source**:

```
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-

unicode_name = u''
utf8_name = unicode_name.encode('utf-8')

print(utf8_name)
print(unicode_name) # This line generate error
```

**Output:**

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "d:\Temp\tmp2.py", line 7, in <module>
    print(unicode_name) # This line generate error
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode characters in position 0-1: ordinal not in range(128)

data.title: capitilization is not consistent for file paths on windows in setbreakpoints message

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.1
- OS Version: windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1) start a debug session
2) add a bp
3) Breakpoint message will likely contain uppercase drive letter
4) Delete bp
5) Breakpoint message will now contain lowercase drive letter

NOTE: I am working around this in our debug adapter. This causes an issue because we have collections of source files that contain bps in the c++ and c# debug adapters. These keys are not found in this case because of the casing mismatch.

data.title: VS Code crashes when previewing large image on Markdown page
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.1.0-stable
- OS Version:Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. create a Markdown page and add the following link:

```
![car](https://static.pexels.com/photos/54278/pexels-photo-54278.jpeg)
```
1. Open Preview, View Source, Open Preview again

Usually crashes VS Code on the second preview.  You might need to try several times.
